qas.question: What publisher did Marvel first license its characters to for novelization?
What was the first novel published under this deal?

answers.text: The Avengers Battle the Earth Wrecker by Otto Binder

qas.question: What was the name of the short-lived Marvel novelization book publisher during the 2000s?
In 2005, Marvel dropped it's own publishing rights for novelization and instead partnered with what publisher?
Marvel Press was relaunched in what year?
Who wrote the Young Adult novel Mary Jane?
How many books did Marvel license with Pocket Books?
What is the name of the company that licensed the majority of marvel comics before 2003?
When did Marvel switch to the Disney Books Group?

context: Marvel first licensed <b7_0>two<b7_0/> prose novels to <a0_0><b8_0>Bantam Books<b8_0/><a0_0/>, who printed <a1_0>The Avengers Battle the Earth Wrecker by <b6_0>Otto Binder<b6_0/><a1_0/> (1967) and Captain America: The Great Gold Steal by <b5_0>Ted White<b5_0/> (1968). Various publishers took up the licenses from 1978 to 2002. Also, with the various licensed films being released beginning in 1997, various publishers put out movie novelizations. In 2003, following publication of the prose young adult novel Mary Jane, starring Mary Jane Watson from the Spider-Man mythos, Marvel announced the formation of the publishing imprint <a2_0>Marvel Press<a2_0/>. However, Marvel moved back to licensing with <a3_0>Pocket Books<a3_0/> from 2005 to 2008. With few books issued under the imprint, Marvel and Disney Books Group relaunched Marvel Press in <a4_0><b9_0>2011<b9_0/><a4_0/> with the Marvel Origin Storybooks line.
